title: Phosphorous Supplement Oral: Uses, Side Effects, Interactions, Pictures, Warnings & Dosing - WebMD
description: Find patient medical information for Phosphorous Supplement oral on WebMD including its uses, side effects and safety, interactions, pictures, warnings and user ratings.
cleaned_text: Uses This drug is used in people who cannot get enough phosphorus from their diets. Phosphorus is a natural body mineral that is needed for the body to work normally. It is needed for building and keeping strong bones. It also helps control the amount of [calcium](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-1575/calcium+oral/details) in the body and urine. How to use Phosphorous Supplement 280 Mg-160 Mg-250 Mg Oral Powder Packet Take this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) by [mouth](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/anatomy-of-the-mouth) as directed by your doctor, usually 4 times a day with meals and at [bedtime](https://www.webmd.com/parenting/childs-bedtime). Open the packet and mix the powder in one-third of a glass (2.5 ounces or 75 milliliters) of water or other liquid such as juice. Stir the mixture well before taking all of it. Dosage is based on your medical condition and response to treatment. Take this medication regularly in order to get the most benefit from it. To help you remember, take it at the same times each day. Take this medication 2 to 3 hours before or after taking any products containing [magnesium](https://www.webmd.com/diet/supplement-guide-magnesium), aluminum, or [calcium](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-1575/calcium+oral/details). Some examples include [quinapril](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-6254/quinapril+oral/details), didanosine, [vitamins](https://www.webmd.com/vitamins-and-supplements/lifestyle-guide-11/vitamin-expert)/ [minerals](https://www.webmd.com/food-recipes/vitamin-mineral-sources), and antacids. Dairy products (such as milk, yogurt), [calcium](https://www.webmd.com/food-recipes/ss/slideshow-gourmet-calcium)-enriched juice, iron, and zinc are also included. These products bind with phosphate, preventing its full absorption. If your doctor has recommended that you follow a special diet, it is very important to follow the diet to get the most benefit from this medication and prevent serious side effects. Do not take other [supplements](https://www.webmd.com/men/video/lamm-supplements-diet)/vitamins unless ordered by your doctor. If you are unsure about how to take this medication, ask your doctor or [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions). Side pain](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/abdominal-pain-causes-treatments) may occur. If any of these effects last or get worse, tell your doctor or [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) promptly. If your doctor has directed you to use this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx), remember that your doctor has judged that the benefit to you is greater than the risk of side effects. Many people using this medication do not have serious side effects. When this medication is first started, there is a chance an old [kidney stone](https://www.webmd.com/kidney-stones/ss/slideshow-kidney-stones-overview) will be passed. Tell your doctor right away if you develop any symptoms of a [kidney](https://www.webmd.com/kidney-stones/picture-of-the-kidneys) stone passing, including: in the urine](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/blood-in-urine-causes). Tell your doctor right away if you have any serious side effects, including: heartbeat, signs of kidney problems (such as change in the amount of urine), tingling/numbness of the hands/feet/lips, confusion, [seizures](https://www.webmd.com/epilepsy/understanding-seizures-basics), unusual [weakness](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/tc/weakness-and-fatigue-topic-overview)/tiredness, shortness of breath. A very serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergic-reaction-causes) to this drug is rare. However, get medical help right away if you notice any symptoms of a serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/anaphylaxis-15/slideshow-allergy-triggers), including: [rash](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/common-rashes), dizziness, [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments). This is not a complete list of possible side effects. If you notice other side effects not listed above, contact your doctor or pharmacist. In the US - Call your doctor for medical advice about side effects. You may report side effects to FDA at 1-800-FDA-1088 or at www.fda.gov/medwatch. In Canada - Call your doctor for medical advice about side effects. You may report side effects to Health Canada at 1-866-234-2345. Precautions Before taking this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx), tell your doctor or [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) if you are allergic to it; or if you have any other [allergies](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergy-relief-10/slideshow-allergy-myths-facts). This product may contain inactive ingredients, which can cause allergic reactions or other problems. Talk to your pharmacist for more details. Before using this medication, tell your doctor or pharmacist your medical history, especially of: high phosphate/ [potassium](https://www.webmd.com/diet/supplement-guide-potassium)/sodium levels, adrenal gland problems (myotonia congenita), [liver disease](https://www.webmd.com/hepatitis/liver-and-hepatic-diseases), [dehydration](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/dehydration-adults), too much body water (such as swelling of arms/legs, fluid in the [lungs](https://www.webmd.com/lung/picture-of-the-lungs)), severe burns/wounds, swelling of the [pancreas](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/picture-of-the-pancreas) ( [pancreatitis](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-pancreatitis)), a diet restricted in sodium or potassium. This medication contains sodium. Consult your doctor for more information if you are on a salt-restricted diet or if increased salt intake could worsen your condition (such as [heart](https://www.webmd.com/heart/picture-of-the-heart) failure). During pregnancy, this medication should be used only when clearly needed. Discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor. It is unknown if this drug passes into [breast](https://www.webmd.com/women/picture-of-the-breasts) milk. Consult your doctor before breast-feeding. Interactions See also How to Use section. [Drug interactions](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/video/vd-0801-atsp-12) may change how your [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) work or increase your risk for serious side effects. This document does not contain all possible drug interactions. Keep a list of all the products you use (including prescription/nonprescription drugs and herbal products) and share it with your doctor and [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions). Do not start, stop, or change the dosage of any medicines without your doctor's approval. Some products that may interact with this drug include: burosumab, corticosteroids (such as [prednisone](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-14590/prednisone+intensol+oral/details)), [digoxin](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-4358/digoxin+oral/details), drugs that are affected by acid levels in the urine (such as [chlorpropamide](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-8635/chlorpropamide+oral/details), [methadone](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-2671/methadone+oral/details)), medications that may increase [potassium](https://www.webmd.com/diet/supplement-guide-potassium) levels (such as potassium [supplements](https://www.webmd.com/men/video/lamm-supplements-diet)/salt substitutes. Overdose If someone has overdosed and has serious symptoms such as passing out or [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments), call 911. Otherwise, call a poison control center right away. US residents can call their local poison control center at 1-800-222-1222. Canada residents can call a provincial poison control center. Symptoms of [overdose](https://www.webmd.com/mental-health/addiction/drug-overdose) may include: severe [diarrhea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-diarrhea), [muscle spasms](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/muscle-spasms-cramps-charley-horse). Do not share this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) with others. Lab and/or medical tests (such as [calcium](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-1575/calcium+oral/details)/phosphorus/ [potassium](https://www.webmd.com/diet/supplement-guide-potassium)/sodium levels, [kidney](https://www.webmd.com/kidney-stones/picture-of-the-kidneys) function) should be done while you are taking this medication. Keep all medical and lab appointments. Consult your doctor for more details. If you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember. If it is near the time of the next dose, skip the missed dose. Take your next dose at the regular time. Do not double the dose to catch up. Store at room temperature away from heat and moisture. Do not store in the bathroom. Keep all [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) away from children and pets. Do not flush medications down the toilet or pour them into a drain unless instructed to do so. Properly discard this product when it is expired or no longer needed. Consult your [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) or local waste disposal company.
